questions.question:
Question 1: The water vapor and pollutants tend to get trapped in the lowermost layers of the atmosphere 
in winters. What is the reason behind this occurrence?
questions.explanation:
In winters, water vapor and pollutants get trapped in the lowermost layers of the atmosphere due 
to temperature inversion. This results in the formation of smog, especially in the winter months, and this is a possible threat 
to human health.

questions.question: Question 2: Which of the following is not an indicator of air pollution?
questions.explanation:
The heavy metal pollution index (HPI) is not an indicator of air pollution. It is a rating method 
and an effective tool to assess the water quality with respect to heavy metals. Indicators of air pollution: • Sulfur dioxide - best indicator • Smoke or soiling index • Grit and dust measurement • The co-efficient of haze • Air pollution index • Suspended particle matter (SPM)

questions.question: Question 3: Which agency monitors air quality in India?
questions.explanation:
Central Pollution Control Board is the main body that monitors air quality in India and sets 
standards.

questions.question: Question 4: Greenhouse gases include all of the following except:
questions.explanation:
Carbon monoxide is not a greenhouse gas. 574 
Sold by @itachibot Greenhouse gases include: • Water vapor • Carbon dioxide • Methane • Tropospheric ozone • Nitrous oxide • Chlorofluorocarbons (non-natural)

questions.question:
Question 5: Which of the following protocols set the standard to reduce the emission of greenhouse gases 
internationally?
questions.explanation:
The Kyoto Protocol was an internal agreement to set internationally binding emission reduction 
targets. It is linked to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change. The parties 
committed to reduce GHGs by 18% in the period between 2013-2020.

questions.question: Question 6: Which of the following is true about global warming?

options.a: Carbon dioxide is the major greenhouse gas
options.c: CFC increases ozone levels in the stratosphere
options.d: Kyoto Protocol called for 10% reduction in greenhouse emissions

questions.explanation:
Carbon dioxide is the major greenhouse gas. Tropospheric ozone and chlorofluorocarbons are also important greenhouse gases. Water vapor is 
the most abundant greenhouse gas, but the water vapor produced directly by human activity 
contributes very little to the amount of water vapor in the atmosphere. Hence, its emissions have 
not been estimated. Greenhouse gases lead to global warming, which is the major cause of climate change. Climate 
change accelerates species extinction on earth.

questions.question: Question 7: Which of the following is incorrect regarding indoor air pollutants?

options.a: Carbon monoxide is produced by fuel combustion
options.c: Radon is an indoor air pollutant
options.d: Mercury vapor is a source of indoor air pollution

questions.explanation:
Mercury is not a source of indoor air pollution. Indoor air pollutants commonly arise from coal or fuel combustion. They include: • Carbon monoxide • Polyaromatic hydrocarbons • Nitrogen • Sulfur oxides • Pesticides • Asbestos 575 
Sold by @itachibot • Lead • Radon

questions.question: Question 8: Which of the following is unlikely to be seen in individuals affected by indoor air pollution?
questions.explanation:
Indoor air pollution has not been linked with neurodevelopmental disorders. It can result in a 
higher incidence of the following: • Pregnancy complications • Chronic lung disease • Childhood pneumonia

questions.question: Question 9: The best indicators for routine monitoring of air pollution are:

options.a: Sulfur dioxide, smoke, and suspended particles
options.b: Sulfur dioxide, lead, and particulate matter

questions.explanation:
The best indicators for routine monitoring of air pollution are sulfur dioxide, smoke, and 
suspended particles.

questions.question: Question 10: Which of the following is not an index of thermal comfort?
questions.explanation:
The heat transfer coefficient is a measure of the heat transfer by convection or phase transition. It 
is not an index of thermal comfort. Thermal comfort is the subjective feeling of temperature in an environment. Optimum levels of 
thermal comfort help to increase productivity. Indices of thermal comfort include the following: Index

questions.question: Question 11: What are the instruments used to measure atmospheric pressure called?
questions.explanation:
Atmospheric pressure or barometric pressure is measured using barometers. The most commonly known barometers are Fortin’s barometer, Kew pattern station barometer, 
and the barograph. The Indian Meteorological Department uses the Kew pattern station 
barometer. The pressure at Earth’s surface, close to sea level averages around 760 mmHg, and man is 
adapted to live around this.

questions.question:
Question 12: What sweat excretion rate in acclimatized, healthy young men is indicative of intolerable air 
temperature?
questions.explanation:
A sweat excretion rate of > 4.5 L /4 hours in acclimatized, healthy young men is indicative of 
intolerable air temperature. This is known as McArdle’s maximum allowable sweat rate. This is the maximum allowable sweat rate that is compatible with the normal physiological 
reaction of acclimatized, healthy young men who are exposed to heat. The predicted four-hour 
sweat rate (P4SR) is obtained from readings of air and mean radiant temperature and air velocity 
under different work intensities. Based on this value, the zone of comfort can be determined. PredictedP4 
SR Zone of comf 
ort Comfort zone 
1 – 3 litres Just tolerable 
3 – 4.5 litres Intolerable 
4.5 + litres

questions.question: Question 13: Identify the following instrument:
questions.explanation: The given image is of a Six’s thermometer.

questions.question: Question 14: The mean radiant temperature is measured by the:
questions.explanation: The mean radiant temperature is measured by the globe thermometer.

questions.question:
Question 15: The given instrument can be used to measure all of the following except: 569 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
577 
Sold by @itachibot The image shown above is of the kata thermometer. It was originally used to measure the cooling 
power of air (air temperature, humidity and air movement) but currently, it is only used to 
measure low air velocities.

questions.question: Question 16: Which of the following is not an index of heat stress?
questions.explanation:
Air velocity index is not an index of heat stress. Heat stress is the load of heat that must be dissipated from the body if it is to remain in thermal 
equilibrium. Factors that affect heat stress are metabolic rate, air temperature, humidity, air 
movement, and radiant temperature. Indices for heat stress are: • Predicted four-hour sweat rate • Equatorial comfort index • Heat stress index.

questions.question: Question 17: Which of the following is unlikely to be seen in individuals suffering from heat stress?
questions.explanation: Numbness is an effect of cold stress, not heat stress. Effects of heat stress include: • Heatstroke • Heat hyperpyrexia • Heat exhaustion • Heat cramps • Heat syncope

questions.question: Question 18: What level of heat stress index correlates with severe heat strain in individuals?
questions.explanation:
A heat stress index of 40–60 indicates severe heat strain. It can pose a threat to health and greatly 
impair work if not fit or acclimatized. Heat stress indices include: • Equatorial comfort index • Predicted four-hour sweat rate (P4SR) • Heat stress index (HSI) 578

questions.question: Question 19: Which of the following is incorrect about cold stress?

options.b: Dry-cold conditions occur at temperatures above freezing
options.c: Cold stress can cause desire to sleep
options.d: Frostbite is common at high altitudes

questions.explanation:
Dry-cold conditions occur at temperatures below freezing and are common at high altitudes. It 
results in complications like frostbite. Wet-cold conditions occur at temperatures above freezing. It results in complications like trench 
foot. Cold stress also causes hypothermia which can induce numbness, loss of sensations, 
muscular weakness, desire to sleep, coma, and death.

questions.question: Question 20: Identify the following instrument shown below:
questions.explanation: The image shown is of a sling psychrometer. Psychrometers are used to measure humidity.

questions.question: Question 21: Which is the most widely used instrument to measure humidity?
questions.explanation: The most widely used instrument to measure humidity is the dry and wet bulb hygrometer.

questions.question: Question 22: What is the following instrument used to measure?
questions.explanation: The image given is that of an Assmann psychrometer which is used to measure humidity. They consists of two thermometers each inside a double tube for minimizing radiative heating.

questions.question: Question 23: Which is the most widely used rain gauge in India?
questions.explanation:
579 
Sold by @itachibot The Government of India prescribes the use of Symon’s rain gauge which is a non-recording type 
of rain gauge. It is used to measure the amount of rainfall. The image below shows the Symon’s rain gauge.

questions.question: Question 24: Which of the following instruments measures the air velocity?
questions.explanation:
Anemometers are used to measure air velocity. Kata thermometers are used as anemometers for low air velocities. The image below shows an anemometer. Wind vanes are used to identify the wind direction (shown below). 580 
Sold by @itachibot The image below shows an anemometer wind vane. 581 
Sold by @itachibot Housing and Ventilation
